text:
-A plane flew over the building,
shook this building.
We're on the 35th floor.
There's 39 stories.

-On September 11, downtown
resident and artist, James

Gilroy, was here in his
apartment on Greenwich Street,

seven blocks from the
World Trade Center.

He was holding his one-year-old
daughter when he
heard a loud noise.

-And I remember thinking what
kind of fool flies that close.

And then there was
a huge explosion.

And this dust cloud comes, and
it's like milk, you know.

It just comes, and it comes
right up to this building, and

I step inside, and it leaves
just a pile of white dust. I
mean, it covers the park.
It covers the buildings.
It covers everything.

It's like somebody spray
painted lower
Manhattan white, ash white.

It covered everything
with dust.

-Surrounded by the dust, Gilroy
tried to find safety
for his family.

-Yeah, you don't know
where to run to.

Plus I've got my wife and the
kid, and I tried to keep a wet
cloth over my daughter's face.
She was screaming.
You know, kids.

You're wrapping a wet cloth
around her head, she's not
going for it.
But I'm still trying.

-A week after the attacks with
smoke still rising from Ground

Zero, EPA Director Christie Todd
Whitman pronounced the

air safe to breathe, and many
downtown residents, including
the Gilroys, returned home.
-There was dust for months.

There was always dust
in the air.

-Gilroy and his neighbors
felt immediate effects.

-You hear talk in
the elevator.

People started to
have reactions.
I have insurance.

I went to see my doctor
and stuff, and
he sent me for tests.

And he said you have some
scarring on your--

you're not getting your
full lung capacity.

It's like you're trying to get
a breath, and you can't get a
full breath.

I don't think that they should
have said go back home.

I don't think they
should have lied.

I think they should have looked
out for people better.

I worry about my kid, what's
going to happen.
I'm an older guy.
I had Anna-May late in life.

It was the greatest thing that's
ever happened to me.

So I worry about my kid
more than anything.
